column2: P5JS - Painting with Sound - Part 2
What you'll do
Continue your quest to turn sound into visuals by adding color and more detection logic!
Hi there! I'm glad you're back, {{user_name}} - I've got something awesome to show you!

First things first - let's get back to the p5.js code editor. You can load your previous sketch (if you saved it at http://editor.p5js.org ), or get back to where we left off: https://editor.p5js.org/madetohack/sketches/7djSSUEJ
Last time, we got a circle to dance around in response to the sounds coming through the microphone – this time, let’s change the way it reacts and add more color.
First, in order to draw a lot of things on top of the background, we need to move our background() function out of draw() and into setup(). Can you think of why that might be?
We need to move that function because if it's in setup(), it only runs once. In draw() it’ll run and repaint the background constantly, which will “erase” anything we put on it.
Now, let’s change your code to only draw a circle if the volume is louder than certain number. To do that, first, let’s delete the current line that draws your circle, in draw()
… And we’ll replace that line with the following: if (volume > 0.1) { (press Enter twice for 2 new lines) }
That code says “If, when we get volume, it’s above 0.1, then do the stuff inside these curly braces. Otherwise, skip it and keep going.” I think you see why it’s usually called a if statement!

Right now, though, we aren’t doing anything inside that if statement - so let’s draw a circle! Inside the curly braces ( {} ) for the if statement, type this code: circle(random(width), random(height), volume * 100);
That’s going to draw a circle in a random position, but at a similar range of sizes to the ‘dancing circle’ you had in the previous activity.
Let’s run this code and see what happens – press the play button and make some noise!
Nice, but the screen filled up pretty quickly. Maybe we should repaint the background and erase all the circles if the volume gets really loud.
To do that, we need to add another if statement, below the first one. Make a new line after the final curly brace ( } ) of the first if statement...
.. and type this: if (volume > 0.3) { (press Enter for a new line) background(150,100,200); (press Enter for a new line) }
Make sure that your if statements both have their own sets of curly braces ( {} ), and that there’s still one last closing curly brace ( } ) at the very end, to end draw().
Let’s run the code again – and this time, make some really loud noise every time to the screen gets too crowded.
Cool! Now, let’s add even more – how about some color?
We’ll add another if statement, below our previous one. Make a new line after the final curly brace ( } ) of the second if statement, and...
You guessed it, type this text: if (volume > 0.2) { (press Enter for a new line) }
That sets up our new if statement, now let's fill it.

Between the opening and closing curly braces ( {} ) you just added, type this: fill(random(255), random(255), random(255)) (press Enter for a new line) circle(random(width), random(height), volume * 100);

That’s 2 lines you’ve added – the first one sets us a random color, and the second one you should recognize from the first if statement you wrote. This will make your circle a random color if the volume is above 0.2. Run it and watch the colors roll in!
Nice work! Are you ready to go ever further? I hope on, because the next activity is going to stretch your brain! See you there!
